newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Zimbabwe shares surge to record on rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Zimbabwe shares surge to record on rate cut.

text.p: Zimbabwe shares rose to a record high on Friday because of lower interest rates and improved inflation prospects, traders said.
The market ignored a continuing strike by thousands of civil servants and the key 57-share index rose 95.85 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at a record 5,675.17.
"The market was bullish in keeping with expectations in an environment where inflation and interest rates are coming down," one broker said.
A market official and share analysts forecast the market will rise further in the next few months as interest rates fall following a central bank cut in a key lending rate.
The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe (RBZ) said on Thursday it had lowered its rediscount rate to 27.5 percent from 29.5 percent with effect from Tuesday, citing a fall in annual inflation.

It last brought down the rate in November 1994 when it eased it to 29.5 percent from 30 percent but had since maintained a tight monetary policy to fight resurgent annual inflation -- pegged at 22 percent in July from 28 percent in January.

"It's welcome news for the stock market and will have a softening effect on lending rates which will be a boost for stocks as people will more likely move funds from the money market to shares," Richard Chitumba, an investment expert with share market analysts Dataworld, told Reuters.
The good news on interest rates was offset by a continuing strike by civil servants pressing for wage rises of between 30 and 60 percent.
Representatives of thousands of strikers, emboldened by strong public support, said on Friday they would remain on the streets despite government threats to sack them.

But the share market focused on interest rates. Zimbabwe Stock Exchange chief executive Anthony Barfoot said there was already "a lot of activity" and share prices were high. "It (the RBZ cut) is likely to push the value of the shares higher because companies should be able to make better profits," he said.
The key industrial index, which has been rising steadily this week on foreign buying, ended Thursday 7.77 points up at 5,579.32.
Stock and money market analyst and columnist Charles Gurney said with falling interest rates, any double digit dividend yield should be able to offer value.
He said the gap between the rediscount and market rates had become "glaringly large" and had limited a recent slide to the lower 20s in short-term trading rates on the money market.
"Counters that are highly geared yet able to exploit the resurgence in economic growth will benefit from the interest rate cuts," said Nigel Chanakira, another share market analyst.
Zimbabwean industrialists have been complaining that punitive borrowing rates of over 30 percent were frustrating expansion plans and eroding profit margins.
On Thursday, the Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries (CZI) said the rate cut would bolster the country's fragile economic recovery from a drought which depressed growth in 1995.
